'''The Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland (CARRS-Q)''' is a research centre established in 1996.
It is based at the Kelvin Grove campus of [[Queensland University of Technology]] (QUT) in Queensland, Australia and is part of both the Faculty of Health and the [[Institute of Health and Biomedical Innovation]] (IHBI).
The Centre was established as a joint venture of the Motor Accident Insurance Commission (MAIC)<ref name="MAIC">Queensland Government - Motor Accident Insurance Commission [http://www.maic.qld.gov.au/about-maic/maic-funding-inits/research-centres.shtml "CONROD and CARRS-Q"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref> and QUT, and also receives funding from competitive research grants for specific projects. CARRS-Q's stated vision is "to decrease the local, national and international burden of trauma-related harm"<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/aboutus/mission.jsp "CARRS-Q: About Us: Our Vision, Mission and Key Outcomes"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref>, which it does by conducting research, training road safety professionals, running drink-driver rehabilitation and fleet safety programs, and giving awards to other organisations or individuals for successful road safety initiatives.
== Areas of research == CARRS-Q's areas of research are divided into Occupational Road Safety, Regulation and Enforcement, Safety Systems and Technology, School and Community Injury Prevention, and Vulnerable Road Users<ref name="MAIC" />. The Centre is part of the School of Psychology and Counselling in QUT's Faculty of Health<ref>QUT Faculty of Health, School of Psychology & Counselling [http://www.hlth.qut.edu.au/psyc/about/index.jsp "Faculty of Health: Psychology and Counselling: About The School"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref>, and some of its researchers have psychology qualifications<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/staff/academic.jsp "CARRS-Q: Staff Profiles: Academic Research Staff"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref> and focus on the behavioural aspects of [[road safety]]<ref>QUT ePrints [http://eprints.qut.edu.au/cgi/search/advanced/?screen=Public%3A%3AEPrintSearch&_action_search=Search&divisions=carrs-q &keywords=behaviour&order=-date%2Fcreators_name%2Ftitle "Advanced Search: Affiliation matches any of "Centre for Accident Research & Road Safety - Qld (CARRS-Q)" AND Keywords matches "behaviour"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref>.
== Teaching activities == Through [[Queensland University of Technology]], CARRS-Q offers a Graduate Certificate<ref>[[Queensland University of Technology]] [http://www.courses.qut.edu.au/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Courses.woa/wa/selectMajorFromMain?studylevel=9&courseID=7457 "PY40 Graduate Certificate in Road Safety"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> or Graduate Diploma<ref>[[Queensland University of Technology]] [http://www.courses.qut.edu.au/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Courses.woa/wa/selectMajorFromMain?courseID=7456 "PY41 Graduate Diploma in Road Safety"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> in Road Safety for people who are already working in, or want to enter the field<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/education/alumni/profiles.jsp "CARRS-Q Alumni Profiles"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>, as well as short courses in crash site investigation and statistical evaluation<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/education/edcourses_short.jsp "CARRS-Q: Road Safety Training and Education"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>. It also has Masters and PhD students, some of whom are concurrently employed as Research Officers<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/staff/postgraduate.jsp "CARRS-Q Postgraduate Students"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>.
== Research Interventions == The Centre has two self-funding research interventions, the Fleet Safety program<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/research/research_fleet1.jsp "Work Related Road Safety"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> and the Under the Limit (UTL) drink-driver rehabilitation program<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/utl/ "Under the Limit (UTL) Drink Driver Education Program"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>.
Organisations that want to improve [[occupational health and safety]] (and thus, reduce costs and risks) in their [[fleet vehicle|vehicle fleets]] can engage the Fleet Safety team to conduct a range of services including driver profiling and policy development<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/research/research_fleet2.jsp "Work Related Road Safety"], 2010. Retrieved on 13 April 2010.</ref>. Workshops, both for fleet managers (using case studies to explore legal obligations and data-collection processes) and professional drivers (focusing on awareness, attitude and behaviours) are conducted<ref>Qfleet: Queensland Government, Department of Public Works [http://www.qfleet.qld.gov.au/Latest%20News/200811.pdf "Journey: CARRS-Q - Driver training"], 2008. Retrieved on 13 April 2010.</ref>, and a series of Fleet Safety seminars have been held<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/community/past_events.jsp "Archive of Past CARRS-Q Events"], 2010. Retrieved on 13 April 2010.</ref>. Fleet Safety is sometimes referred to as Work Related Road Safety.
Convicted drink drivers are referred to the Under the Limit program (in conjunction with a probation order) through the [[Magistrates' Court of Queensland]]<ref>Legal Aid Queensland [http://www.legalaid.qld.gov.au/Legal+Information/Cars+and+driving/Drink+driving+offences.htm "Drink driving offences"] 2006. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>. Completion of the program has been shown to reduce repeat drink-driving offences, although it does not change participants' intentions to drink<ref>Australian Government Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government [http://www.infrastructure.gov.au/roads/safety/publications/2001/Alc_Rehab_3.aspx "CR 187: The Impact of the "Under the Limit" Drink Driving Rehabilitation Program on the Lifestyle and Behaviour of Offenders (2001)"], 17 June 2008. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>. The UTL program is held at [[Technical and Further Education]] (TAFE) campuses and in 2009 received the Queensland Crime & Violence Prevention Award from the [[Government of Australia]]'s [[Australian Institute of Criminology]]<ref>Australian Institute of Criminology [http://www.aic.gov.au/crime_community/acvpa/2009.aspx "2009 Australian Crime & Violence Prevention Awards"], 9 November 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref><ref>Australian Institute of Criminology [http://www.aic.gov.au/media/2009/october/20091029-5.aspx "Qld drink driving rehabilitation receives anti-crime award"], 29 October 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>.
== Research facilities == CARRS-Q has a range of equipment used in road safety research on driver behaviour, including an instrumented [[four-wheel drive]] (4WD) vehicle and a [[driving simulator]].
The instrumented 4WD is equipped with sensors such as a multimedia [[datalogger]], physiological devices ([[EEG]], [[ECG]] and [[Electromyography|EMG]]), [[laser]] scanner, [[radar]]s and [[eye tracking|eye trackers]]<ref>Queensland University of Technology: [http://www.marketingcomm.qut.edu.au/cmpublications/insidequt/iqut/IQ266.pdf "Inside QUT: 4WD mindset"], 2006. Retrieved on 15 April 2010.</ref>.
The CARRS-Q Driving Simulator was officially launched on 19 March 2010<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/simulator/index.jsp "CARRS-Q: Advanced Driving Simulator"], 2010. Retrieved on 10 March 2010.</ref>. It is based on a [[Holden Commodore]] sedan that was donated for the purpose, and sits on a [[six degrees of freedom]] [[motion platform]]<ref>Queensland University of Technology [http://www.youtube.com/user/TheQUTube#p/u/8/FAs2oxTqznE "QUT CARRS-Q driving simulator launch"], 24 March 2010. Retrieved on 30 March 2010.</ref>.
==Queensland Road Safety Awards== The Queensland Road Safety Awards (QRSA) were first held in the year 2000<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/qrsa/winners/ "QRSA: Previous Winners"], 2009. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref> and are a joint initiative of CARRS-Q and the [[RACQ]] to "recognise and honour the outstanding efforts of individuals and groups who have started projects or programmes to improve safety on Queensland roads"<ref>Royal Automobile Club of Queensland [http://www.racq.com.au/about_us/community/sponsorship/road_safety_awards "RACQ: Road Safety Awards"], 2008. Retrieved on 11 November 2009.</ref>.
== Collaboration == CARRS-Q has links with similar organisations worldwide, such as the French National Institute for Transportation Safety Research ([[INRETS]]) and [[University of Michigan]] Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI), through exchange of visiting researchers<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/staff/visiting.jsp "Staff Profiles: Visiting Research Staff"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref> and collaboration on research papers<ref>Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety - Queensland [http://www.carrsq.qut.edu.au/publications/research.jsp "Research Publications"], 2009. Retrieved on 12 November 2009.</ref>.
